4.author: MeadowmuffinReborn
4.body:
Topical references don't really bother me, in fact I love them, but that may be more of my personal taste and you see it differently. 

To me, topicality in movies and other media represents a snapshot of the time and place  of when it was made, and to me, that gives it a texture and verisimilitude. 

Like in Knocked Up, Leslie Mann gets upset because she wants to see Spider-Man 3 with her husband, which instantly dates that movie to 2007. I *like* that kind of stuff. It makes it feel more real. 

If she had wanted to go see a made up movie instead, or like an ersatz of Spider-Man called Spider-Dude or something, that would take me out of the reality of the film.

An odd thing: the words "Dawn of Man" appear about 4 minutes into the movie.  The next title card, "Jupiter Mission 18 Months Later," appears at about 55 minutes into the movie.  So, one could interpret the first 55 minutes of the movie are *still* just the dawn of man, that the modern humans at that point are not much more evolved(?) than the creatures at the beginning, even with their spacecraft. I do not claim that is the only way or the best way to think about those three words--there are many other ways.

27.author: Alive_Ice7937
27.body:
> A lot of theaters don't have good sound systems

If a studio wants a wide release for a film then they have to try and account for the variety of systems it will be seen on. This isn't an unreasonable expectation given that the overwhelming majority of films released since the advent of film sound have managed to achieve this.

And a lot of people had issues with the sound in Tenet in modern premium theatres in which they had watched many other films without a problem.

27.author: yojoono
27.body:
I think a lot of Nolan's audio problems could be fixed if he used a sound format other than 5.1 surround sound so he could spread the sounds out a bit more, and if he stopped using the audio recorded while people are wearing masks. 
I'm fine with how loud Nolan wants his films to be played, but I feel like he needs to use 7.1 more or Atmos to let him spread the sounds among more speakers so he can get the loudness he wants. It would let many speakers share the load with 7 speaker channels or more instead of blasting all the sound out of 5 channels. 

Although, his main problem is the voices of people wearing masks. That's been a problem of his since for a while lol. I do feel like the audio problems in Tenet were exaggerated, but I can definitely see scenes where it there could be issues like when they're sailing on the boat.

27.author: Alive_Ice7937
27.body:
Mixing for a format that's only going to be available to a small portion of the audience for a short period of time would be a bold move for a 200 million dollar movie.

He should mix his sound in a way that dialogue is audible on the myriad of sound systems that it will be heard on. This is an incredibly low bar that pretty much every other wide release movie manages to clear.

Also most dialogue gets on large budget films get rerecorded including Nolan's.

27.author: yojoono
27.body:
Mixing for Atmos would allow for easy down-mixing for other formats like 7.1, 5.1, 2.1 and stereo. Most theaters have a 7.1 setup too so Nolan isn't using them to their full potential. You can make an Atmos mix on any Mac computer if you have software like Logic pro so it isn't that crazy to do. Nolans's mixes have been music-heavy for years and I doubt that will change. Almost all high-budget movies and TV shows have an Atmos Mix, and most large music labels are trying to get their popular music mixed in Atmos, so mixing for that format is totally reasonable. Almost all phones have Atmos support now, and pretty much all TV's, Soundbars, AV recievers do as well.

Nolan apparently [doesn't like using ADR and will avoid using it](https://ew.com/article/2011/12/09/dark-knight-rises-prologue-christopher-nolan/#:~:text=I%20don't%20like%20to,like%20we%20did%20with%20Inception.) if possible so idk. He said he uses 35 and 65mm cameras during dialogue since the IMAX camera runs too loud to record good audio. Tenet used an IMAX camera for a bunch of it so that could've added more issues.

Tenet was made for the best systems, so using Atmos would've been a no-brainer, however 70mm IMAX Film only has 6 tracks of audio on it so that could be the limiting factor. Nolan is a film purist after all.

27.author: Alive_Ice7937
27.body:
>Mixing for Atmos would allow for easy down-mixing for other formats like 7.1, 5.1, 2.1 and stereo. Most theaters have a 7.1 setup too so Nolan isn't using them to their full potential.

Since the film is going to be viewed in all of those formats shouldn't the dialogue at least be audible on all of them? Again something that every other widley distributed film manages to achieve. 


>Tenet was made for the best systems, so using Atmos would've been a no-brainer, however 70mm IMAX Film only has 6 tracks of audio on it so that could be the limiting factor. Nolan is a film purist after all.

And in the past he's not had any issues with dialogue intelligibility when working within those limitations of film. Nobody ever complains about not being able to hear the dialogue in Inception or The Dark Knight. So although mixing in Atmos may be a solution to this problem, Nolan's refusal to do that isn't the root of the problem. Both he and countless other filmmakers have managed to make dialogue audible across multiple formats. Something has changed in his approach to sound that has really soured it for the audience. I hate having to read CC captions telling me that [stirring music continues]. But that's a choice Nolan and his production team are now forcing audiences to make. If poor dialogue sound is a common complaint with Oppenhiemer then I'll simply not pay to see it.
